metadata.case_name: Appellants v. India Fisheries P Ltd.

facts.text: The respondent was a private limited company directed to be wound up by order of Bombay High Court dated October 11, 1950, and a Court Liquidator was appointed as Official Liquidator with powers under s.179 of the Indian Companies Act, 1913 to be exercised under s.180 without sanction except for sales of immovable property.
For assessment year 1948-49, respondent assessed on December 8, 1950, tax Rs. 8,737/15/-. Income Tax Officer lodged claim on or about March 15, 1951 with Official Liquidator.
Claim adjudged and allowed as ordinary claim and certified on April 2, 1952.
In August 1954, Official Liquidator declared dividend of 9 1/2 annas in a rupee and paid Income Tax Department Rs. 5,188/3/-, leaving balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- payable.
For year 1955-56, Department made demand on June 22, 1954 for Rs. 2,565/6/- as advance tax, paid by Official Liquidator.
On regular assessment for 1955-56, Rs. 1,126/12/- assessed as payable. After adjusting against advance Rs. 2,565/6/-, Rs. 1,460/1/- refundable inclusive of interest.
Income Tax Officer set off refund against balance of Rs. 3,549/12/- outstanding for 1948-49.
Respondent filed revision to Commissioner of Income-tax, rejected on September 21, 1959, holding action justified under s.49E.
Respondent filed petition under Art. 226 on November 25, 1959, praying to set aside orders, restrain set-off, direct handover to Official Liquidator.
Bombay High Court judgment and order dated February 22, 1961 in Miscellaneous Application No. 352 of 1959, setting aside set-off orders, directing Income Tax Officer to deal with refund under s.48.
Appeal to Supreme Court pursuant to certificate under Art. 133(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Income Tax Officer could set off the refund due under s.49E of Income Tax Act against the tax claim for 1948-49 which had been proved and certified as an ordinary unsecured debt in the winding up proceedings under Companies Act.
Whether s.49E is subject to the insolvency rules in ss.228 and 229 of Companies Act, 1913, in winding up of insolvent company.

petitioner_arguments.text: s.49E gives statutory power to Income Tax Officer to set off amount to be refunded against tax remaining payable, not subject to any provision of any other law; Companies Act does not take away this power.
Application under Art.226 misconceived as Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction.

respondent_arguments.text: Demand for 1948-49, once adjudged and certified as ordinary claim, has incidents of unsecured debt payable by Official Liquidator governed by Companies Act; no longer 'tax remaining payable' under s.49E.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held that proved claim is governed by Companies law, paid only per Company law provisions; s.49E not available once claim proved in winding up.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim has character of unsecured debt; no other remedy available to creditor.

court_reasoning.text: s.49E not subject to other laws on face, but cannot defeat Companies Act provisions; State has no priority for this claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unsecured creditor must prove debt; all paid pari passu per ss.228,229.

court_reasoning.text: s.49E general provision; ss.228,229 special in liquidation; s.49E applies when insolvency rules do not apply. Special prevails in conflict.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reconciled by holding s.49E inapplicable in insolvency.

court_reasoning.text: Art.226 jurisdiction proper: lack of jurisdiction or error apparent on face of orders.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Income Tax Officer erred in applying s.49E.

holdings.text: s.49E of Income Tax Act not available to Department for setting off refund against proved claim in company winding up; subject to insolvency rules in ss.228,229 Companies Act.
Income Tax Officer to deal with refund claim under s.48 Income Tax Act.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s.49E allows set-off of refund against tax payable but inapplicable once claim proved in winding up; s.48 for handling refunds.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of Official Liquidator; debts to be proved in winding up; insolvency rules apply pari passu to unsecured creditors.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ jurisdiction to quash erroneous orders.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed agreeing with High Court; set aside Income Tax Officer's set-off under s.49E and Commissioner's affirmation; directed Income Tax Officer to dispose of refund claim under s.48.
outcome.relief_granted: Set aside set-off orders; direct handling of refund under s.48 Income Tax Act.

key_quotes.text: once the claim of the Department has to be proved and is proved in the liquidation proceedings, the Department cannot by exercising the right under s. 49E of the Income Tax Act get priority over the other unsecured creditors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on pari passu principle and inapplicability of s.49E.

key_quotes.text: If there is an apparent conflict between two independent provisions of law, the special provision must prevail.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains reconciliation: Companies Act special over general s.49E.
